title: 109_s2636
content: The "Oil Company Accountability Act" may be cited as the short title. It introduces an Energy Tax Rebate under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Oil Company Accountability Act" introduces an Energy Tax Rebate under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Each individual is treated as having made a $500 payment against the tax for the taxable year beginning in 2006, with certain exceptions. The Secretary will remit the payment to taxpayers within 30 days of enactment. The Oil Company Accountability Act allows for an Energy Tax Rebate under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Certain individuals, estates, trusts, and nonresident alien individuals are eligible for the rebate. A conforming amendment is made to title 31, United States Code, and a clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for subchapter B of chapter 65 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Energy Tax Rebate under the Oil Company Accountability Act will take effect upon enactment. Additionally, there will be a revaluation of LIFO inventories for large integrated oil companies. The Oil Company Accountability Act requires applicable integrated oil companies to increase the value of historic LIFO inventories and decrease cost of goods sold for the last taxable year ending in 2005. If the increases exceed the cost of goods sold, gross income will be adjusted accordingly. The term "layer adjustment amount" is defined for this purpose. The Oil Company Accountability Act mandates integrated oil companies to adjust historic LIFO inventories and cost of goods sold for the last taxable year ending in 2005. If the adjustments exceed the cost of goods sold, gross income will be increased accordingly. The term "layer adjustment amount" is defined as $18.75 multiplied by the number of barrels of crude oil represented by the layer. The term "applicable integrated oil company" is defined in this section, and any adjustments required by this section will not be considered a change in accounting method. Additionally, no tax additions will be made for underpayments of estimated tax due to adjustments made under this section. For tax purposes, an "applicable integrated oil company" is defined as a company with significant oil production and high gross receipts. All related entities are treated as one for tax purposes, and special rules apply for short taxable years. MODIFICATIONS OF FOREIGN TAX CREDIT RULES APPLY TO LARGE INTEGRATED OIL COMPANIES WHO ARE DUAL CAPACITY TAXPAYERS. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to include special rules for large integrated oil companies that are dual capacity taxpayers. Any amount paid to a foreign country or possession of the United States by such companies will not be considered a tax under certain conditions. The Internal Revenue Code includes special rules for large integrated oil companies that are dual capacity taxpayers. Any amount paid to a foreign country or possession of the United States by such companies will not be considered a tax if certain conditions are met. The term 'dual capacity taxpayer' refers to a person subject to a levy of a foreign country or possession of the United States, who receives a specific economic benefit from that country or possession. This is defined in the Internal Revenue Code for large integrated oil companies. The term 'generally applicable income tax' refers to an income tax imposed by a foreign country or possession on income derived from a trade or business within that country. It does not include taxes that do not apply to persons who are not dual capacity taxpayers. The term 'large integrated oil company' is defined as an integrated oil company with gross receipts exceeding $1,000,000,000 and an average daily worldwide production of at least 500,000 barrels of crude oil. The amendments made by this section apply to taxes paid or accrued in taxable years beginning after the enactment of this Act, except where contrary to any treaty obligation of the United States.
